awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Predictive theory, synthesis and characterization of a new type of transparent conductor without doping
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description: Technologies such as photovoltaic solar cells, smart windows, light emitting diodes, touch-screen sensors, electronic papers, and flat panel displays require for their operation a critical component that is both an electrical conductor and optically transparent, the so-called transparent conductors. These compounds are unique, as transparency and conductivity are generally mutually exclusive properties of compounds. Indeed, optical transparency (as in window glass) is generally associated with electrical insulation, whereas electrical conductivity (such as in copper or gold) is generally associated with optically opaque metals. Known transparent conductors such as indium oxide doped with Sn are made by instilling conductivity in transparent insulators. The research team aims to develop a novel family of transparent conductors - metallic ceramics - by designing transparency in metals. This presents a new method to design optical properties as distinct from electronic properties. The approach has an exciting intellectual impact as it suggests a general approach for inverse design - starting from science-based design principles used as 'filters' for computational material selection, followed by identification of representative examples and then laboratory validation. The graduate students and postdocs of CU Boulder and Northwestern Universities are given exciting opportunities to participate in this cutting edge research effort.

Technical description: Transparent conducting oxides are paradoxical materials that form the basis of modern day technologies, such as touch screens, flat panel displays, solar panels, etc. The current method of choice for discovering new transparent conductors have relied on heavily doping transparent insulators until they become conducting. Unfortunately, wide band gap materials are intrinsically resistant to doping of charges because of the existence of so-called 'doping bottlenecks'. Namely, the introduction of a high concentration of free carriers into insulators generally leads to the spontaneous formation of structural defects with polarity that compensate that of the intentional doping. Consequently, the progress in finding and optimizing such technologically critical transparent conducting oxide materials has been frustratingly slow. The research team proposes an opposite, and likely more fruitful alternative of designing transparency in metals by looking for compounds that obey a set of 'design principles' with specific band structures. The design rules for such intrinsic transparent conductors are: (i) identify a compound with metallic band structure; such that (ii) it has low plasma frequency and (iii) low inter-band optical absorption across the Fermi level, and (iv) apply synthesis and characterization to the 'best of class' compounds, here Ba-Nb-O. The most visible advantage of metallic transparent conductors is that their conductivity comes from their high, indigenous carrier concentration. The complex theory-experimental approach in the proposal enables more efficient progress as alternative to the previously used trial-and-error method.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The fields of electronics, photonics and spintronics are currently blossoming with new physical phenomena and significant applications ranging from data storage and telecommunications to information processing, therefore becoming an important topic for physics, chemistry, and materials science. Our research focuses on advancing Electronics, Photonics and Spintronics by discovery, synthesis and characterization of the appropriate Materials that harbor such functionalities.

Transparent conductors (TCs), combining optical transparency and electrical conductivity that are usually incompatible due to the interaction between electric carriers and incident light, are the basis for many technological applications, such as solar cells, touch screens, etc. Over the course of this project, our group has theoretically designed and synthesized a new form of TCs without doping. The idea of research on intrinsic TCs starts from the discovery of an opaque metal that already has plenty of free carriers and then one designs optical transparency. This is very different than the current approach of doping wideband gap insulators until they become conducting, which soon runs into issues of solubility limits and lattice strain. Following these theories, we have studied a variety of routes towards theoretically predicted intrinsic transparent conducting oxides in the Ba-Nb-O system, such as Ba3Nb5O15, and in the Ag-Al-O system, such as Ag3Al22O34, see Fig 1. As those compounds have ordered vacancies, the Fermi level lies inside the conduction band, but they also have a sufficiently large band gap below the Fermi level, allowing the design of transparency by interband optical transitions and intraband plasmonic frequencies. Another new TC, TaIrGe prepared by our group provides excellent examples to understand the intrinsic semiconducting behavior in all-metal heavy-atom TCs. We further discovered that the degenerate insulators could exhibit antidoping: electron anti-doping shifts the doped band into the principal valence band, instead of the common case of extra electrons shifting Fermi level towards the conduction band. Such antidoping increases the band gap and thus reduces the conductivity, which is a key factor to be considered in the design of transparent conductors.

Compare to a conventional electronic device which only relies on the electronic charge carriers, spintronic devices also have the spin degree of freedom, which provides new capabilities and functionalities. Based on our experience in studying TCs, we have explored more compounds where the spin action replaces the charge action of electrons. We proposed a type of Dresselhaus effect (D-1B), which exists in polar symmetries such as ferri-chiral crystals, and exhibits spin splitting that can be reversed upon a change in chirality. Focusing on alkali metal chalcogenides, we identified NaCu5S3 in the ferri-chiral structure, which exhibits CuS3 chiral units differing in the magnitude of their Cu displacements. We synthesized NaCu5S3 crystals and confirmed their ferri-chiral structure. In the crystals, both left-handed and right-handed structures as well as their domain walls were identified and characterized by electron microscopy, see Fig 2. Our electronic structure calculations have demonstrated it exhibits D-1B spin splitting as well as a ferri-chiral phase transition, revealing spin splitting interdependent on chirality. A few percent biaxial tensile strain can reduce (or nearly quench) the switching barrier separating the monodomain ferri-chiral states. Our study suggests the design of ferri-chiral crystals as potential spintronic and optoelectronic materials.

Several graduate students and postdocs in this project were trained in inorganic chemistry, solid-state physics, and optoelectronics. The PI and students gave plenary talks on TCs and spintronics. To date, the project has produced multiple peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in development.

Malyi, Oleksandr I., Michael T. Yeung, Kenneth R. Poeppelmeier, Clas Persson, and Alex Zunger. "Spontaneous non-stoichiometry and ordering in degenerate but gapped transparent conductors." Matter 1, no. 1 (2019): 280-294.

Huang, Pu, Zhiguo Xia, Xiaoqing Gao, James M. Rondinelli, Xiuwen Zhang, Han Zhang, Kenneth R. Poeppelmeier, and Alex Zunger. "Ferri-chiral compounds with potentially switchable Dresselhaus spin splitting." Physical Review B 102, no. 23 (2020): 235127.

Antonyshyn, I., F. R. Wagner, M. Bobnar, O. Sichevych, U. Burkhardt, M. Schmidt, M. Konig et al. "Micro‐Scale Device - An Alternative Route for Studying the Intrinsic Properties of Solid‐State Materials: The Case of Semiconducting TaGeIr." Angewandte Chemie International Edition 59, no. 27 (2020): 11136-11141.
